last_replies.com:
>>90251921
Even if you promise no breaking changes, bugs are an inevitability. Gnome can be putting in their best effort to ensure that if your program works with 3.0.1 it's also gonna work with 3.0.2 and sometimes it still doesn't work. And packagers of course can't test every possible combination of dependency + dependent every time they update a package. So they just ship it and then the 1% probability event happens to a small proportion of the user base and their file explorer or login greeter or window manager breaks and everyone who isn't a programmer with desire to tinker fucks off to windows and warns all their friends to stay away from Linux.

Windows knows this, which is why most windows programs ship with a specific version of their dependencies, that are tested by the application developer and known to work. These dependencies are not updated except by the application that uses them. Yes, it means you'll have 20 different versions of .Net Framework simultaneously. Yes, the 1gb extra space taken by this does not cause windows computers to explode.

Ubuntu does the second best thing, which is to pick specific versions for everything and test them all together. So that their packagers have a hope of testing every combination of dependency + dependent. And it also kinda works, until you need newer versions of things or go beyond what the packagers have managed to test.

com:
https://www.osnews.com/story/135605/the-mass-extinction-of-unix-workstations/

As x86 became ever more powerful and versatile, and with the rise of Linux as a capable UNIX replacement and the adoption of the NT-based versions of Windows, the days of the UNIX workstations were numbered.

A few years into the new millennium, virtually all traditional UNIX vendors had ended production of their workstations and in some cases even their associated architectures, with a lacklustre collective effort to move over to Intel's Itanium — which didn't exactly go anywhere and is now nothing more than a sour footnote in computing history.

Approaching roughly 2010, all the UNIX workstations had disappeared.... and by now, they're all pretty much dead (save for Solaris). Users and industries moved on to x86 on the hardware side, and Linux, Windows, and in some cases, Mac OS X on the software side....

Over the past few years, I have come to learn that If you want to get into buying, using, and learning from UNIX workstations today, you'll run into various problems which can roughly be filed into three main categories: hardware availability, operating system availability, and third party software availability.

Their article details their own attempts to buy one over the years, ultimately concluding the experience "left me bitter and frustrated that so much knowledge — in the form of documentation, software, tutorials, drivers, and so on — is disappearing before our very eyes."

Software is dying off at an alarming rate, and I fear there's no turning the tide of this mass extinction.

The article also wonders why companies like HPE don't just "dump some ISO files" onto an FTP server, along with patch depots and documentation.

> "This stuff has no commercial value, they're not losing any sales, and it will barely affect their bottom line.

last_replies.com:
Imagine a social media site where the entire server-side software is a black box. Ie, it's encrypted in such a way that the server doesn't know where any given post is stored in memory, nor exactly which individual posted it. This social media site would be text only for obvious reasons, but even then it's just a matter of time before somebody says something that hurts some politician's feelings and they come to shut it down.

Who would be legally liable at this point? My understanding is that it's the poster who would be at fault, but the site administrator could be compelled to dox the poster. But what happens when the administrator turns over the logs and it includes a list of people who posted but isn't able to match those IPs to individual posts due to a technical limitation? Is the site of the hook at that point or is there an actual law somewhere that specifies the exact pieces of user identifiable information that must be collected and stored?

Disclaimer: I haven't tested it

#!/bin/bash
# CAPS = Constants as a convention
# They're not gonna change while you run the program

main () {
    set_magnet "${@}"
    set_webchecker
    set_health
    echo "${health}"
}

urlencode () {
    # urlencode <string>
    local length="${#1}"
    for (( i = 0; i < length; i++ )); do
        local c="${1:i:1}"
        case "${c}" in
            [a-zA-Z0-9.~_-]) printf '%s' "${c}"      ;;
            *)               printf '%%%02X' "'${c}" ;;
        esac
    done
}

set_health () {
    health=$(\
            curl -s "${webchecker}" \
            -H 'Accept: */*' \
            -H 'Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5' \
            -H 'Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br' \
            -H 'Connection: keep-alive' \
            -H 'Referer: https://checker.openwebtorrent.com/' \
            -H 'Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty' \
            -H 'Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors' \
            -H 'Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin' \
            | jq -r '. | "Seeders \(.seeds)","Leechers \(.peers)"'
    )
}

set_magnet () {
    magnet=$(\
        urlencode "${1}"
    )
}

set_webchecker () {
    webchecker="https://checker.openwebtorrent.com/check?magnet=""${magnet}"
}

main "${@}"

Is it possible to make html website with bare ruby without using ruby on rails?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90250951
require 'socket'

server = TCPServer.new('0.0.0.0', 8080)

loop do
  socket = server.accept

  request = socket.gets
  puts request

  response = "
  <!doctype html>
  <html>
    <head>
      <title>My Ruby Website</title>
    </head>
    <body>
      <h1>Hello, world!</h1>
    </body>
  </html>
  "

  socket.print "HTTP/1.1 200 OK
" +
               "Content-Type: text/html
" +
               "Content-Length: #{response.bytesize}
" +
               "Connection: close
"

  socket.print "
"
  socket.print response

  socket.close
end

>Is a dating app an example of SAAS?
No, not even close.
SAAS means what you sell is your software solution as the product, it is something you sell to help your customers solve a business problem. Figma is a SAAS, it solves business problems. Tinder or Duolingo is just consumer apps. Google Translate is both, you can use it as a service to translate texts for your business, for example incorporate it into your own app to offer translation or text2speech service from inside your own app. Same with Google Maps, both a consumer product and a SAAS.

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html

last_replies.com: Too many people are scared of silence or feeling 'bored' nowadays. That is why the average person is constantly with at least one earphone/airpod thing at all times. The wireless technology of airpods just made the problem worse - when wires were dangling it was less pleasant to constantly have them in - but now you can wear them and do just about anything without inconvenience. People love those atmospheric playlists also - so if they aren't listening to a podcast or music, they are still bombarding their senses with more ear candy. I am critical of it, because I found myself becoming like those people not too long ago, I was constantly listening to something, even if I was talking to people irl. Basically, I went the other direction and started looking into monks and people that do ascetic practices. In Catholicism there is a heavy focus on self-denial and silent contemplation. I used that stuff as motivation to be silent for a certain amount of time each day, go to bed without anything playing, reading books without ambient music, being more present when talking to people irl. Honestly, I feel so much better. It is a real addiction that does beat your senses down and your ability to concentrate if you let it, you may think you are unaffected, but try doing a bit of a detox from constant noise and you will be amazed by the changes in your energy and mood. Spend time in silence with your own thoughts. Exercise without music, drive without music.

com:
This is the best browser. It's not just competently made - a fork of the best browser on the market, but it's also not made for profit or malicious intent. It has no callbacks to Google out of the box, and is made by good devs who don't have to wrestle with Mozilla every update or so (Google is far more lax with updates resetting settings and breaking things generally). Optionally, you can get full access to Google's web store which contains more extensions than any other browser, and you don't have to justify using a hipster browser when other people see you use your PC.

You're getting a top notch big-tech browser the way it should've been. A win-win really.
Most people use Chrome, so it's also easier to make the transition to this browser without it feeling like a cheap knock-off (aka Firefox in 2022).

You cannot refute this without slippery slope fallacies like "W-well if you use Ungoogled, Google will win the browser market!". First off, they already have. And Mozilla are aiding them by striking deals with them and selling your info to them, and that's just the best case scenario. Second, not using superior technology because of a slippery slope is retarded. It's literally luddite thinking in the same vein as "If we don't get the vaccine, our economy will collapse". Thirdly, why would you want to help promote shitty software like Firefox in the first place? Even Brave is better, but Brave likes to change personalization settings to shill crypto, so it's really Brendan's browser and not yours; unlike Ungoogled.

People do a lot of irrational things, but not using Ungoogled Chromium is one I just don't think I'll ever understand.

Lighting can be performed at rasterization time, pre-baked or in real-time (ray-traced). Almost all games use a mix of those three methods, with virtually all lighting still done with the first two methods. AMD does very well with the first two methods, but much less well with real-time RT. Doom only uses a few RT lighting effectss per scene, so AMD does well. A game like Icarus does most of the lighting with RT, and only a little with rasterization/baked, so AMD does less well there but still good enough to play. Quake 2 RTX and Portal RTX are in a different league and do all of the lighting with RT and additionally do away with rasterization entirely for certain scenes, so AMD does absolutely shit there.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90240578
RAID 1 is the only real option for redundancy with only two drives. If you start putting larger numbers of drives together, you can build systems where you only need as many extra drives as you want to be able to fail without losing data (like a 5 drive array where 1 can fail, and you have as much storage as 4 drives, or an 8 drive array where 2 can fail, which is a good idea since it's not too rare to have a second drive fail during resyncing when the first drive fails, and you have as much storage as 6 drives).

But you might as well go for more. The price/capacity sweet spot is around 8TB drives now.

com:
I know there are a lot of Linux users on this board, but I wanted to throw in my two cents and encourage you to give MacOS a try. I was a diehard Linux user for years, but after switching to MacOS, I've never looked back.

First and foremost, MacOS is just so much more user-friendly and intuitive than Linux. The user interface is clean and easy to navigate, and there's a much wider range of user-friendly, easy-to-use software available for MacOS than there is for Linux.

Additionally, MacOS is much more stable and reliable than Linux. I've never had to troubleshoot a problem or deal with system crashes on my Mac the way I did with Linux. And because MacOS is developed and supported by Apple, you can always count on regular updates and support if you need it.

Finally, MacOS just looks so much better than Linux. The aesthetic design is sleek and modern, and there are a ton of customization options available to make your system look and feel exactly the way you want it to.

All in all, I know there are diehard Linux fans out there, but if you're willing to give MacOS a try, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised by how much better it is. Give it a shot and see for yourself!
